summary: A video tutorial helping users resolve a Skype login issue by disabling UPnP.

events_list.video_caption: The video showcases a computer desktop with a Skype login window open, featuring a blue background with a cloud and rainbow design. The user has entered the Skype name "joearisto" and is in the process of typing a password. The desktop is cluttered with various icons, including Sticky Notes, Skype, and other applications. The Sticky Notes application displays three notes with different colors and text, including a green note with "IP 69.72.200.52 Port 3318" and a yellow note with "Sappataris." The user is seen typing on the password field, and the Skype login window shows a loading icon, indicating that the login process is underway. The desktop background features a scenic landscape with a cloudy sky. The video captures the user's interaction with the Skype login window and the surrounding desktop environment.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a male speaker welcoming listeners to a video tutorial that serves as a follow-up to a tutorial on his blog. He mentions that he will provide the link later. He then proceeds to describe how the user attempts to log in to Skype, enters their password, and encounters a "spinning icon" instead of logging in. The speaker says that this is undesirable and states that you must quit Skype. A loud, distorted buzz is then heard.

events_list.video_caption: The video showcases a computer desktop with a scenic background featuring a rainbow over a forested landscape. The desktop is cluttered with various icons, including Skype, Sticky Notes, and other applications. Initially, the Skype login window is open, prompting the user to enter their Skype name and password. The user then closes the Skype window, revealing the desktop's full view. Subsequently, the Skype 'Options' window appears, displaying settings for connection and advanced options. The user navigates through the 'Options' window, exploring different settings and clicking on the 'Save' button. Throughout the video, sticky notes with text such as "IP 69.72.200.52 Port 3128" and "Yappatlasr" are visible on the left side of the screen, indicating some form of note-taking or task management. The video concludes with the 'Options' window still open, showing the user's interaction with the Skype settings.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a male speaker stating, "Yes, we want to quit Skype, definitely." He continues with instructions on how to navigate the Skype settings, emphasizing the need to quit the application to access options. The speaker then moves on to explain the connection options, instructing the listener to enter a port within a specific range, describing the number as "a five-figure number starting with six."

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a computer desktop screen displaying various icons and applications, including Sticky Notes, Skype, and other software. The Skype application is open, showing the 'Options' window with settings for connecting to the internet, including options for port and authentication. The user interacts with the Skype application, navigating through the settings and eventually closing the 'Options' window. The Skype login screen appears, prompting the user to enter their Skype name and password. The user types in the name 'Joao' and a password, then clicks the 'Sign in' button. The video concludes with the Skype application successfully logging in, displaying the main Skype interface with options for tasks such as configuring the desktop and uninstalling the program from the taskbar. The background of the desktop features a scenic landscape with a rainbow, and the overall atmosphere is calm and organized.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio features a male speaker describing a process that involves entering a port number and connecting through HTTPS proxy, mentioning the challenge of disabling UPMP in this context. He says "you're supposed to enter a port number" and speaks in a relatively clear, informative tone. He then transitions to discussing a workaround for this challenge, mentioning he will show how to solve the issue. The sound of someone canceling something is then heard. The speaker announces that they quit Skype.  He notes that a lot of back and forth is happening to solve the issue.

events_list.video_caption: The video showcases a computer desktop with a scenic wallpaper featuring a rainbow over a mountainous landscape. The desktop is cluttered with numerous icons, including applications like Adobe Reader, HP Photosmart, and Skype, as well as folders and shortcuts. In the foreground, a Sticky Notes application is open, displaying three notes with text: "IP 69.72.200.52 Port 3128," "Squapstalis," and "<Disabled>PHP-1</Disabled>PHP-1." The user initiates a file search, typing "Squapstalis" into the search bar, which leads to the opening of a file explorer window. The search results reveal a folder named "Roaming" containing various subfolders and files, including one named "Skype." The user navigates into the "Skype" folder, where they find a file named "shared.xml." Upon opening this file with Notepad, the contents are displayed, revealing a series of XML tags and data, including "config version="1.0" serial="18" timestamp="1376502629," and other technical details. The video concludes with the Notepad window open, showing the XML data, while the Sticky Notes application remains visible in the background.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip features a single male speaker explaining how to edit a file, referencing the Windows logo and describing a process involving clicking "start", typing commands, and opening folders. He maintains an instructional tone throughout. He further describes steps such as opening with Notepad and editing an XML file, with the aim of disabling UPNP.

events_list.video_caption: The video showcases a computer desktop with various applications and files open. On the left side, there are sticky notes with text such as "JP 097.72.200.52" and "Pop 318" in green and yellow notes, and "DisablePHP1/DisablePHP" in a purple note. The central focus is on a Notepad window displaying a configuration file with lines like "config version=1.0" and "serial=18" among others. The desktop background features a scenic landscape, and icons for Skype, Adobe Reader, and other applications are visible. The taskbar shows the time as 8:00 am and the date as 06/06/2013. The video progresses with the Notepad window being closed and replaced by a Skype window, revealing a list of folders and files, including "shared.ani" and "shared.xml." The sticky notes remain unchanged throughout the video, and the desktop environment stays consistent with no significant alterations.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip features a single male speaker discussing a technical issue. He uses a casual and instructional tone, mentioning that something "doesn't show in the user interface." He then instructs the listener to "copy this here" or "type in this code." After this technical explanation, he details how to paste the code under the "connection" tag. He concludes that it is "very good" and instructs the listener to close and save. Finally, he states "Voila," and suggests restarting Skype to see if it works. The clip ends with speech and an unidentifiable sound.

events_list.video_caption: The video showcases a computer desktop with a scenic background featuring a rainbow over a mountainous landscape. The desktop is populated with various icons, including Skype, Sticky Notes, and other applications. Initially, the Skype login window is open, displaying the Skype logo and options to sign in with a Microsoft account or create a new account. The user attempts to log in with the username 'joaristio' and a password, but encounters an error message stating 'Unable to connect to Skype servers. Please try again later.' The user then navigates to the Skype options window, specifically the 'Connection' tab, where they select 'Use port' and enter '3318' in the 'Port' field. The video concludes with the Skype options window still open, showing the 'Use port' option selected and the port number '3318' entered, while the login window remains visible in the background. Throughout the video, sticky notes with various texts are visible on the left side of the screen, and the desktop icons remain unchanged.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a single male speaker stating "Okay", then explaining the next action: "Practice Skype." He continues by explaining the next step: "We go to tools, connection options again." He adds reassurance with "And don't worry if you don't see the enable UPMP down here, it has already been disabled in the shared XML file," before guiding again: "So we come here".

events_list.video_caption: The video showcases a computer desktop with a focus on the Skype application's options window. The desktop is cluttered with various icons, including Sticky Notes, Adobe Reader, and several others, indicating a busy workspace. The Skype options window is open, displaying settings for connection preferences, such as the choice between using a port or sharing a port, and options for automatic proxy detection and disabling proxy authentication. The user is seen interacting with the window, specifically selecting the 'Use port' option and entering a port number. The sticky notes on the desktop contain text, one of which reads "IP 69.72.200.52 Port 3128" and another with "Disabled/PHP/Disabled/PHP," suggesting some form of technical or debugging notes. The background features a scenic wallpaper with a field and a clear sky, adding a touch of nature to the otherwise tech-focused environment. The video captures the user's interaction with the Skype settings, highlighting the customization options available for the application's connection preferences.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip features a single speaker, who gives instructions on entering a five-digit port number that doesn't start with six. The speaker then instructs to select HTTPS for connecting through proxy. The speaker further references going to a blog with an address that contains the name 'joearisto', and indicates it is a 'blogspot.com' address. The speaker speaks in a calm and instructional tone.

events_list.video_caption: The video showcases a computer desktop with various applications and sticky notes. Initially, the Skype application is open, displaying the 'Options' window where the user configures the connection settings, including the use of port 443 for incoming connections and the IP address 69.67.72.200.52. The user then closes the 'Options' window and proceeds to log out of Skype, as indicated by the 'Sign Out' button. Subsequently, the user attempts to log back in, entering the username 'joariasto' and a password, with the Skype login screen visible. The desktop background features a scenic landscape with a rainbow, and various icons for applications such as Adobe Reader, Dropbox, and Skype are visible. Sticky notes with text are also present, one of which reads 'IP 69.67.72.200.52 Port 3188 joariasto's [DisabledPHP-1] [DisabledUPnP] [joariasto.blogspot.com]'. The video concludes with the Skype login screen still open, awaiting the user's credentials.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip consists of one male speaker who talks in an instructional tone. He mentions ".com" and refers to "updated IP addresses and ports", explaining how to paste certain values into a field. Towards the end, he expresses some relief as he says "it works at last". Background sounds and some voice qualities lead to the impression that it is some kind of recording.

events_list.video_caption: The video showcases a computer desktop with a Skype application open, displaying a user named "Aristide Boushey." The Skype window reveals a list of contacts on the left, including "Rendard Jazanah," "Betty Board Ave," "Echo / Sound Test Service," and "Yellow Bird 911." The main area of the Skype window features a message from "Christi," stating, "Christi is in the vessel. I will always smile with captain Steve." Below this message, there is a reply from "Mr. Owamz" with a link to a YouTube video. The desktop background is a scenic image with a Bing logo at the bottom. On the left side of the screen, there are sticky notes with text, including "JP 69.772.200.52 Port 3138 Supp1at1n's -CDisabledUPH-1-DisabledUPH- jenista.blogspot.com." The desktop icons include Google Chrome, Microsoft Word, and other applications. The video captures the Skype interface and desktop environment without any significant changes or actions occurring.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio features a male speaker, providing assistance with a technical issue. He suggests leaving a message under the blog post with any challenges and assures the listener that he will be happy to help. His tone is helpful and encouraging, and he wishes the listener a pleasant experience with Skype. Then the speaker says goodbye.
